problem: Given that $j$, $\frac{1}{j}$, $k$, $\frac{1}{k}$, $l$, $\frac{1}{l}$, $m$, $\frac{1}{m}$, $n$, $\frac{1}{n}$, $o$, $\frac{1}{o}$, $p$, $\frac{1}{p}$, $q$, $\frac{1}{q}$, $r$, $\frac{1}{r}$, $s$, $\frac{1}{s}$, $t$, $\frac{1}{t}$, $u$, $\frac{1}{u}$, $v$, $\frac{1}{v}$, $w$, $\frac{1}{w}$, $x$, $\frac{1}{x}$, $y$, $\frac{1}{y}$, $z$ and $\frac{1}{z}$ are all integers, how many distinct values of $x+ y+ z$ are possible?
